Analysis.name: Breastfeeding exclusivity short-term 1 to 3 months post-intervention
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Computer-generated random numbers using mode of delivery and parity as stratifying factors to control for these variables. Unclear how allocation concealment was handled.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Participants and people delivering intervention were aware of allocation. ITT conducted.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: Nearly half of the intervention arm dropped out after allocation but before the start of treatment. Very few dropped out from the control arm at any point.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: Outcomes were completed online independently. Outcome assessors who monitored data were not blinded.
Bias.in.selection.of.the.reported.result: No published protocol; through communication with author, we know there was a protocol but were not given access to this.
Overall.bias.support: A well-conducted study marred primarily by the loss of participants from the intervention group.

Analysis.name: Breastfeeding exclusivity short-term 1 to 3 months post-intervention
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Sealed opaque envelopes, allocation by research assistant.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: An antenatal breastfeeding education where person receiving intervention and person delivering aware of assignment to intervention. ITT analysis.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: 15% attrition rate in both intervention and control group.
Bias.in.selection.of.the.reported.result: Data analysis plan in thesis, however, no information on whether this was published before outcome data was available for analysis.
Overall.bias.support: Participants and those delivering intervention aware of assigment to intervention. No published protocol or trial registration before data available for analysis.

Analysis.name: Breastfeeding exclusivity short-term 1 to 3 months post-intervention
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Random assignment with random numbers list; permutation blocks; external statistician used. Allocation concealed from researchers, recruited, and participants. Groups appear unbalanced with regard to in-hospital supplementation rate.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Participants in the trial were given access to a postpartum breastfeeding clinic with professional help.  ITT analyses.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: Loss to follow-up 14.6% in intervention group compared to 6.3% in control group.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: Telephone interview and survey used to measure outcome. These however, not standardised questionnaires which could be influenced by knowledge of intervention received. Research staff non-blinded to assigment when collecting data.
Bias.in.selection.of.the.reported.result: Trial registered at clinicaltrials.gov beforehand and a protocol was published before outcome data was analysed.
Overall.bias.support: High risk of bias because of groups being unbalanced due to higher supplementation rate in control group. Exclusive breastfeeding primary outcome of the study. More than twice as large loss to follow-up in intervention compard to control group.

Analysis.name: Breastfeeding exclusivity short-term 1 to 3 months post-intervention
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: "allocated, by means of randomly ordered cards in sealed opaque envelopes"
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Since the control group was also a video, delivered in the same way, this could be seen as a credible placebo if midwives did not show a preference for the breastfeeding video, and if participants were unaware the breastfeeding video was the intervention of interest.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: Only 47% follow-up.  Authors analysed baseline data and found no important differences between participants and those who dropped out. Unclear whether high drop-out rate would be related to outcome.
Bias.in.selection.of.the.reported.result: Not enough information. No indication that results were selected.
Overall.bias.support: The high drop out rate is concerning and may introduce bias.

Analysis.name: Breastfeeding exclusivity short-term 1 to 3 months post-intervention
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Participants were randomly assigned to the intervention or control group using a random number table. No information about concealment.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Those delivering intervention aware of participants receiving intervention. Results not analysed according to ITT.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: Telephone interviews and survey used to measure exclusive breastfeeding. Same timepoints and same interview conducted for both groups when data collected. Assessors collecting data blinded to the group allocation of participants. However, data on breastfeeding and mental health collected through face-to-face interviews which could introduce bias as mother's not anonymous and considering stigma of mental health and pressure to breastfeed could lead to false answers.
Bias.in.selection.of.the.reported.result: Same WHO definition used at same time points.
Overall.bias.support: No allocation concealment of participants. Results not analysed according to ITT. Survey data on breastfeeding collected through face-to-face interviews which could introduce bias.
